BIOS307
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit. This transition, from basic cancer biology to the implementation of patient diagnosis and treatment, is called "translational cancer research" and is a major focus of the Department of Molecular and Clinical Cancer Medicine, whose scientists will teach the module.
The aims of this module are:
1) Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2) Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient, and
3) Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials (formative feedback).
Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. Each lecture will inform a tutorial, and tutorials will be student-led and will have one theme question (based on the corresponding lecture) to facilitate discussion.
This module will use two assessment approaches:
1) Formative: Tutorials.
2) Summative: Two essays: Essay 1, which will cover the introductory block; and Essay 2, which will cover the cancers-specific blocks.
Educational Aims
1. Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2. Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient.
3. Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit.
On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
1. Critically evaluate phenotypic behaviours of a cancer cell using knowledge of cellular functions, in order to identify possible points of therapeutic intervention.
2. Critically analyse, evaluate and align altered oncogene/tumour suppressor gene functions, DNA repair mechanisms and cellular processes to the pathological consequences for the patients.
3. Understand the role of cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms in cancer development.
4. Critically appraise discovery pathways for new diagnostic and prognostic cancer biomarkers.
5. Analyse signalling pathways likely to become novel therapeutic targets in the near future.
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. The subject of each tutorial will be based on the corresponding lectures, and student will lead the discussion during the tutorial sessions.
This module will use two assessment approaches: Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose and will provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. Summative: It will comprise two essays. Essay 1: to be held on week 6mid-semester, covering the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark. Essay 2: to be held on week 14 at the end of the semester, covering the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Fundamental principles of cancer research
2. Cellular and molecular basis of cancer - Hallmarks of cancer and cancer genetics
3. Molecular basis of cancer - Cell signalling pathways
4. Molecular basis of cancer - DNA Repair/Apoptosis
5. Cancer Epigenetics
6. Molecular pathology of cancer - histopathology of cancer
7. Cancer and energy metabolism
8. Tumour microenvironment
9. Cancer immunology
10. Principles of cancer metastasis
11. Cancer model systems
12. Tumour imaging
13. Systems Biology - Cancer genomics
14. Cancer therapeutics
15. Epidemiology of cancer
16. Clinical trials (cancer)
17. Cancer Biomarkers
18. Early cancer detection
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials:

Lectures: There are 18 lectures (2 lectures/week; face-to-face). Each lecture will inform a tutorial; hence they will be released in advance of the tutorial of the same title.

Tutorials: There will be one tutorial session per week, covering 2 lectures. Tutorials will start with two theme questions to facilitate discussion (the subject of each tutorial will be the two corresponding lectures). Session will be delivered by the staff member who gave the corresponding lecture (which will build confidence and active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)) and will be student-led (will build confidence and global citizenship through positive action and celebration of diversity within the student cohort (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)). Students are expected to have attended and/or watched the corresponding lectures.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will use two assessment approaches:

Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose with respect to content and use past exam questions to set the theme for the tutorial. These past exam questions will not exactly match the format used in the current year. Nevertheless, the tutorials should provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. These will build confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Summative: The summative assessment will comprise two essays.

Essay 1: to be held mid-semester, the 1000 words essay covers the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark.

Essay 2: to be held at the end of semester, the 1500 words essay covers the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

The essays will present scenarios that will prompt to describe a subject (knowledge assesses) and present a critical analysis on the subject (assesses of understanding and reasoning). Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Overview
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit. 3) Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials (formative feedback).

This module will use two assessment approaches:
1) Formative: Tutorials.
2) Summative: Two essays: Essay 1, which will cover the introductory block; and Essay 2, which will cover the cancers-specific blocks.
Educational Aims
1. Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2. Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient.
3. Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients.

The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit.
On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
1. Critically evaluate phenotypic behaviours of a cancer cell using knowledge of cellular functions, in order to identify possible points of therapeutic intervention.
2. Critically analyse, evaluate and align altered oncogene/tumour suppressor gene functions, DNA repair mechanisms and cellular processes to the pathological consequences for the patients.
3. Understand the role of cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms in cancer development.

5. Analyse signalling pathways likely to become novel therapeutic targets in the near future.

Summative: It will comprise two essays. Essay 1: to be held on week 6mid-semester, covering the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark. Essay 2: to be held on week 14 at the end of the semester, covering the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

This module will cover the following topics:

1. Fundamental principles of cancer research
2. Cellular and molecular basis of cancer - Hallmarks of cancer and cancer genetics
3. Molecular basis of cancer - Cell signalling pathways
4. Molecular basis of cancer - DNA Repair/Apoptosis

9. Cancer immunology

12. Tumour imaging

18. Early cancer detection
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials:

Lectures: There are 18 lectures (2 lectures/week; face-to-face). Each lecture will inform a tutorial; hence they will be released in advance of the tutorial of the same title.

Tutorials: There will be one tutorial session per week, covering 2 lectures. Tutorials will start with two theme questions to facilitate discussion (the subject of each tutorial will be the two corresponding lectures). Session will be delivered by the staff member who gave the corresponding lecture (which will build confidence and active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)) and will be student-led (will build confidence and global citizenship through positive action and celebration of diversity within the student cohort (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)). Students are expected to have attended and/or watched the corresponding lectures.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will use two assessment approaches:

Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose with respect to content and use past exam questions to set the theme for the tutorial. These past exam questions will not exactly match the format used in the current year. Nevertheless, the tutorials should provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. These will build confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Summative: The summative assessment will comprise two essays.

Essay 1: to be held mid-semester, the 1000 words essay covers the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark.

Essay 2: to be held at the end of semester, the 1500 words essay covers the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

The essays will present scenarios that will prompt to describe a subject (knowledge assesses) and present a critical analysis on the subject (assesses of understanding and reasoning). Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS307
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit. This transition, from basic cancer biology to the implementation of patient diagnosis and treatment, is called "translational cancer research" and is a major focus of the Department of Molecular and Clinical Cancer Medicine, whose scientists will teach the module.
The aims of this module are:
1) Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2) Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient, and
3) Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials (formative feedback).
Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. Each lecture will inform a tutorial, and tutorials will be student-led and will have one theme question (based on the corresponding lecture) to facilitate discussion.
This module will use two assessment approaches:
1) Formative: Tutorials.
2) Summative: Two essays: Essay 1, which will cover the introductory block; and Essay 2, which will cover the cancers-specific blocks.
Educational Aims
1. Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2. Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient.
3. Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit.
On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
1. Critically evaluate phenotypic behaviours of a cancer cell using knowledge of cellular functions, in order to identify possible points of therapeutic intervention.
2. Critically analyse, evaluate and align altered oncogene/tumour suppressor gene functions, DNA repair mechanisms and cellular processes to the pathological consequences for the patients.
3. Understand the role of cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms in cancer development.
4. Critically appraise discovery pathways for new diagnostic and prognostic cancer biomarkers.
5. Analyse signalling pathways likely to become novel therapeutic targets in the near future.
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. The subject of each tutorial will be based on the corresponding lectures, and student will lead the discussion during the tutorial sessions.
This module will use two assessment approaches: Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose and will provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. Summative: It will comprise two essays. Essay 1: to be held on week 6mid-semester, covering the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark. Essay 2: to be held on week 14 at the end of the semester, covering the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Fundamental principles of cancer research
2. Cellular and molecular basis of cancer - Hallmarks of cancer and cancer genetics
3. Molecular basis of cancer - Cell signalling pathways
4. Molecular basis of cancer - DNA Repair/Apoptosis
5. Cancer Epigenetics
6. Molecular pathology of cancer - histopathology of cancer
7. Cancer and energy metabolism
8. Tumour microenvironment
9. Cancer immunology
10. Principles of cancer metastasis
11. Cancer model systems
12. Tumour imaging
13. Systems Biology - Cancer genomics
14. Cancer therapeutics
15. Epidemiology of cancer
16. Clinical trials (cancer)
17. Cancer Biomarkers
18. Early cancer detection
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials:

Lectures: There are 18 lectures (2 lectures/week; face-to-face). Each lecture will inform a tutorial; hence they will be released in advance of the tutorial of the same title.

Tutorials: There will be one tutorial session per week, covering 2 lectures. Tutorials will start with two theme questions to facilitate discussion (the subject of each tutorial will be the two corresponding lectures). Session will be delivered by the staff member who gave the corresponding lecture (which will build confidence and active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)) and will be student-led (will build confidence and global citizenship through positive action and celebration of diversity within the student cohort (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)). Students are expected to have attended and/or watched the corresponding lectures.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will use two assessment approaches:

Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose with respect to content and use past exam questions to set the theme for the tutorial. These past exam questions will not exactly match the format used in the current year. Nevertheless, the tutorials should provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. These will build confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Summative: The summative assessment will comprise two essays.

Essay 1: to be held mid-semester, the 1000 words essay covers the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark.

Essay 2: to be held at the end of semester, the 1500 words essay covers the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

The essays will present scenarios that will prompt to describe a subject (knowledge assesses) and present a critical analysis on the subject (assesses of understanding and reasoning). Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

4. Critically appraise discovery pathways for new diagnostic and prognostic cancer biomarkers.
5. Analyse signalling pathways likely to become novel therapeutic targets in the near future.
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. The subject of each tutorial will be based on the corresponding lectures, and student will lead the discussion during the tutorial sessions.
This module will use two assessment approaches: Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose and will provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. Summative: It will comprise two essays. Essay 1: to be held on week 6mid-semester, covering the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark. Essay 2: to be held on week 14 at the end of the semester, covering the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Fundamental principles of cancer research
2. Cellular and molecular basis of cancer - Hallmarks of cancer and cancer genetics
3. Molecular basis of cancer - Cell signalling pathways
4. Molecular basis of cancer - DNA Repair/Apoptosis
5. Cancer Epigenetics
6. Molecular pathology of cancer - histopathology of cancer
7. Cancer and energy metabolism
8. Tumour microenvironment
9. Cancer immunology
10. Principles of cancer metastasis
11. Cancer model systems
12. Tumour imaging
13. Systems Biology - Cancer genomics
14. Cancer therapeutics
15. Epidemiology of cancer
16. Clinical trials (cancer)
17. Cancer Biomarkers
18. Early cancer detection
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials:

Lectures: There are 18 lectures (2 lectures/week; face-to-face). Each lecture will inform a tutorial; hence they will be released in advance of the tutorial of the same title.

Tutorials: There will be one tutorial session per week, covering 2 lectures. Tutorials will start with two theme questions to facilitate discussion (the subject of each tutorial will be the two corresponding lectures). Session will be delivered by the staff member who gave the corresponding lecture (which will build confidence and active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)) and will be student-led (will build confidence and global citizenship through positive action and celebration of diversity within the student cohort (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)). Students are expected to have attended and/or watched the corresponding lectures.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will use two assessment approaches:

Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose with respect to content and use past exam questions to set the theme for the tutorial. These past exam questions will not exactly match the format used in the current year. Nevertheless, the tutorials should provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. These will build confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Summative: The summative assessment will comprise two essays.

Essay 1: to be held mid-semester, the 1000 words essay covers the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark.

Essay 2: to be held at the end of semester, the 1500 words essay covers the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

The essays will present scenarios that will prompt to describe a subject (knowledge assesses) and present a critical analysis on the subject (assesses of understanding and reasoning). Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS307
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit. This transition, from basic cancer biology to the implementation of patient diagnosis and treatment, is called "translational cancer research" and is a major focus of the Department of Molecular and Clinical Cancer Medicine, whose scientists will teach the module.
The aims of this module are:
1) Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2) Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient, and
3) Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials (formative feedback).
Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. Each lecture will inform a tutorial, and tutorials will be student-led and will have one theme question (based on the corresponding lecture) to facilitate discussion.
This module will use two assessment approaches:
1) Formative: Tutorials.
2) Summative: Two essays: Essay 1, which will cover the introductory block; and Essay 2, which will cover the cancers-specific blocks.
Educational Aims
1. Develop in-depth knowledge and understanding of the biology of cancer.
2. Integrate this knowledge of biology of cancer with the pathogenesis of the disease in a cancer patient.
3. Translate this understanding of cancer pathogenesis to the clinical actions to benefit patients.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module will train you in molecular oncology, with an emphasis on how scientific advances are translated into clinical practice for patient benefit.
On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
1. Critically evaluate phenotypic behaviours of a cancer cell using knowledge of cellular functions, in order to identify possible points of therapeutic intervention.
2. Critically analyse, evaluate and align altered oncogene/tumour suppressor gene functions, DNA repair mechanisms and cellular processes to the pathological consequences for the patients.
3. Understand the role of cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms in cancer development.
4. Critically appraise discovery pathways for new diagnostic and prognostic cancer biomarkers.
5. Analyse signalling pathways likely to become novel therapeutic targets in the near future.
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials. The subject of each tutorial will be based on the corresponding lectures, and student will lead the discussion during the tutorial sessions.
This module will use two assessment approaches: Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose and will provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. Summative: It will comprise two essays. Essay 1: to be held on week 6mid-semester, covering the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark. Essay 2: to be held on week 14 at the end of the semester, covering the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Fundamental principles of cancer research
2. Cellular and molecular basis of cancer - Hallmarks of cancer and cancer genetics
3. Molecular basis of cancer - Cell signalling pathways
4. Molecular basis of cancer - DNA Repair/Apoptosis
5. Cancer Epigenetics
6. Molecular pathology of cancer - histopathology of cancer
7. Cancer and energy metabolism
8. Tumour microenvironment
9. Cancer immunology
10. Principles of cancer metastasis
11. Cancer model systems
12. Tumour imaging
13. Systems Biology - Cancer genomics
14. Cancer therapeutics
15. Epidemiology of cancer
16. Clinical trials (cancer)
17. Cancer Biomarkers
18. Early cancer detection
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching will be delivered in the form of lectures and tutorials:

Lectures: There are 18 lectures (2 lectures/week; face-to-face). Each lecture will inform a tutorial; hence they will be released in advance of the tutorial of the same title.

Tutorials: There will be one tutorial session per week, covering 2 lectures. Tutorials will start with two theme questions to facilitate discussion (the subject of each tutorial will be the two corresponding lectures). Session will be delivered by the staff member who gave the corresponding lecture (which will build confidence and active learning (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)) and will be student-led (will build confidence and global citizenship through positive action and celebration of diversity within the student cohort (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)). Students are expected to have attended and/or watched the corresponding lectures.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will use two assessment approaches:

Formative: Tutorials have a formative purpose with respect to content and use past exam questions to set the theme for the tutorial. These past exam questions will not exactly match the format used in the current year. Nevertheless, the tutorials should provide students with a reference for the level expected in the examinations. These will build confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework)

Summative: The summative assessment will comprise two essays.

Essay 1: to be held mid-semester, the 1000 words essay covers the introductory block. This assessment comprises 40% of the final module mark.

Essay 2: to be held at the end of semester, the 1500 words essay covers the cancers-specific blocks. This assessment comprises 60% of the final module mark.

The essays will present scenarios that will prompt to describe a subject (knowledge assesses) and present a critical analysis on the subject (assesses of understanding and reasoning). Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
